metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (eddy covariance system of Daman Superstation, 2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Daman superstation eddy covariance system (EC) in the midstream reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2020. The site (100.37223° E, 38.85551° N) was located in the Zhangye City in Gansu Province. The elevation is 1556.06 m. The EC was installed at a height of 4.5 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500A) was 0.17 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 10% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.1 m/s. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. 
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of data processing steps taken for eddy covariance data to ensure quality and reliability?
Example.Answer: Data processing steps for eddy covariance data include outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. These steps are necessary to ensure the quality and reliability of the processed data.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when collecting data on energy and carbon exchanges in inland river basins of arid regions?
Example.Answer: A challenge faced during data collection in inland river basins of arid regions includes environmental degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, which can affect the stability and accuracy of ecological data collection.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the essential characteristics of eddy covariance systems used in the field of oasis-desert ecosystems?
Feature Specification.Answer: CSAT3 ultrasonic anemometer, Li7500A CO2/H2O analyzer, fixed height of 4.5 meters, sampling frequency of 10 Hz, oriented towards true north, 30-minute averages.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the primary features of datasets used to study energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in arid regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: wind direction, wind speed, water vapor density, CO2 concentration, friction velocity, Obukhov length, sensible heat fluxes, latent heat fluxes, CO2 flux, radiation, soil heat flux, soil moisture profiles

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with data collection in arid and semiarid regions?
Definition.Answer: Data collection in arid and semiarid regions faces challenges such as ecological environment degradation, which includes the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These challenges are particularly prevalent in inland river basins along the Silk Road, like the Tarim River basin, the Aral Sea basin, and the Lake Urmia basin. These environmental issues can affect the stability and accuracy of data collection in these regions.

Definition.Question: What constitutes a comprehensive dataset for studying oasis–desert systems, and what types of data are typically included?
Definition.Answer: A comprehensive dataset for studying oasis–desert systems typically includes long-term observations of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, along with auxiliary hydrometeorological data. This involves radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, soil moisture profiles, and groundwater table data. Additionally, vegetation and soil parameters are supplemented to provide a holistic understanding of the ecosystem dynamics in oasis–desert areas.

Comparison.Question: In terms of addressing challenges in arid and semiarid regions, how do the observational datasets from the middle and lower reaches of the HRB compare with those from other inland river basins like the Tarim River or Lake Urmia basin?
Comparison.Answer: The observational datasets from the HRB focus on long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, capturing the oasis–desert interactions crucial for ecological stability and socioeconomic development. In contrast, other inland river basins face similar ecological degradation challenges but might not have equivalent datasets available, highlighting a potential difference in data availability and research focus.

Interpretation.Question: How do data collection methods using eddy covariance systems contribute to understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: Eddy covariance systems provide half-hourly turbulent flux data, which are essential for quantifying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert ecosystems. This detailed monitoring helps in recognizing the interactions between these systems, supporting ecological stability and socioeconomic development by providing long-term observational data critical for sustainable development goals.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise in maintaining data quality and accuracy when collecting long-term observational datasets in arid and semiarid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in maintaining data quality and accuracy include dealing with ecological degradation such as drying rivers and lakes, land desertification, and dust storms. These factors can affect the reliability of instruments like eddy covariance systems and automatic weather stations, necessitating rigorous data processing and quality control procedures to ensure reliable data for understanding ecological interactions.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can data from hydrometeorological observations and vegetation/soil parameters enhance our understanding of oasis–desert system dynamics?
Interpretation.Answer: Hydrometeorological observations and vegetation/soil parameters provide auxiliary data that complement flux measurements, offering a comprehensive view of the ecosystem. This data can enhance understanding by revealing how different environmental variables interact, thereby aiding in the assessment of oasis–desert dynamics such as energy balance, water cycles, and carbon fluxes, which are crucial for managing ecological stability and achieving carbon neutrality.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to the need for specific data processing steps such as coordinate rotation and frequency response correction when handling eddy covariance data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for specific data processing steps like coordinate rotation and frequency response correction arises from the requirements to accurately interpret turbulent fluxes and other measurements in eddy covariance data. These steps help in correcting for any misalignments of the sensor with respect to the wind flow and in compensating for the attenuation of high-frequency signals, ensuring the reliability and accuracy of the observed data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a necessity to exclude data around precipitation events and during instrument errors in flux measurements?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Excluding data around precipitation events and during instrument errors is necessary because these conditions can introduce anomalies and inaccuracies in flux measurements. Precipitation can affect the sensor's ability to measure certain variables accurately, and instrument errors can result in unreliable data, thus necessitating their removal to maintain data quality.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons for conducting long-term observations in oasis–desert ecosystems to understand energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observations in oasis–desert ecosystems are crucial to understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange due to the complex interactions and variability over time. These ecosystems are vital for maintaining ecological stability and agricultural productivity, and understanding their dynamics is essential for achieving sustainable development and ecological security. Long-term data collection provides insights into seasonal and annual trends, which are critical for informed management and policy decisions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of implementing quality control and data processing procedures in the collection of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing quality control and data processing procedures can result in more reliable and accurate data, which is crucial for understanding the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems. It supports ecological security and sustainable development by ensuring data integrity, which is necessary for achieving goals like carbon peaking and neutrality.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems for sustainable development?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Understanding these characteristics is crucial to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of maintaining long-term observational datasets for energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to gain quantitative understanding of the oasis–desert interactions, which is significant for protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to establish a network of land surface flux and meteorological stations in arid regions like the Heihe River Basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Establishing this network helps in collecting comprehensive datasets that include energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, which are essential for understanding the ecological and hydrometeorological dynamics of these regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to ensure the quality and reliability of data collected from eddy covariance systems in arid oasis-desert regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data is processed using Eddypro software which includes steps like outlier removal, time lag correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, sonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Data quality is evaluated based on atmospheric stability and turbulence characteristics, and further filtering is performed by removing erroneous instrument data, excluding data during precipitation, and excluding data with over 10% missing rate in 30-minute intervals.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are involved in the data archiving and sharing process for datasets related to oasis-desert systems in the Heihe River Basin?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedure includes data collection, processing, and subsequent archiving and sharing. The dataset, which includes energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, along with hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters, is made available through the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center, ensuring accessibility for further research and analysis.

Enablement.Question: What technologies or instruments are essential for collecting data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The collection of data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems is enabled by technologies such as eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations. These instruments measure various parameters including turbulent flux, radiation, soil heat flux, air temperature, humidity, wind speed, and soil moisture profiles.

Enablement.Question: What are the conditions necessary for establishing a comprehensive observation network in desert-oasis ecosystems to support sustainable development?
Enablement.Answer: Establishing a comprehensive observation network in desert-oasis ecosystems requires conditions such as strategic location selection in critical areas like the middle and lower reaches of river basins, long-term observational capabilities, and the integration of diverse datasets including energy, water vapor, carbon fluxes, hydrometeorological data, and vegetation and soil parameters. Collaboration with data centers for data archiving and sharing is also essential.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in obtaining accurate measurements of carbon, water vapor, and energy exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face ecological degradation challenges, such as river and lake drying and vegetation degradation, which complicate accurate measurement. Furthermore, the complex interactions between oasis and desert systems require long-term and precise observations to understand energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which is crucial for maintaining ecological stability and supporting sustainable development.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected benefits of using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers in data collection for oasis–desert ecosystem studies?
Expectation.Answer: Eddy covariance systems and scintillometers provide crucial half-hourly turbulent flux data that enhance the quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert areas. This data is essential for recognizing interactions within these ecosystems, contributing to ecological stability and supporting socioeconomic development of oases by providing insights necessary for achieving carbon peaking and neutrality goals.

Expectation.Question: Why might the processing and quality control of observational data be particularly challenging in the context of oasis–desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: The complex environmental conditions in oasis–desert ecosystems, such as land desertification and frequent dust storms, present significant challenges for data accuracy and reliability. The data processing and quality control procedures need to account for these factors to ensure the integrity of the data, which involves steps like error data removal, precipitation-related data exclusion, and handling missing data during the collection and processing phases.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in ensuring the quality and accuracy of data collected through eddy covariance systems in arid and semi-arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face ecological challenges such as river and lake drying, vegetation degradation, and increased dust storms, which may affect data collection. Ensuring data quality involves steps like outlier removal, delay correction, and frequency response adjustment, all of which require careful methodological application.
